channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Across Turkey, New Unrest as Teenage Boy Is Buried
item.description: More than 100,000 mourners in Istanbul attended a funeral procession for a 15-year-old felled by a police tear-gas canister, and new unrest erupted.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Riot police used tear gas to disperse protesters on Wednesday.

item.title: Blips on Radar Baffle Officials in Malaysian Jet Inquiry
item.description: Officials said they were struggling to interpret signals showing what could be the missing aircraft veering sharply off course and hundreds of miles away from its last known position.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Indonesian Air Force officers at a base in Medan, Indonesia, examined a map of the Strait of Malacca after a search operation.

item.title: Gaza-Israel Escalation Threatens Cease-Fire
item.description: The militant group Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility for a rocket attack, the most intense barrage since the cease-fire of 2012.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers and civilians near a hole caused by a rocket launched from the Gaza Strip, in the city of Sderot on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: When Voting in India, What’s in a Name?
item.description: The author fondly recalls his first campaign experience in Mumbai, which included electoral rolls full of misspellings and typewritten “love letters” to a candidate.
item.dc:creator: By DILIP D'SOUZA

item.title: Ukraine Crisis Limits Merkel’s Rapport With Putin
item.description: With Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany failing to sway President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Ukraine, Germans are wondering whether a policy of conciliation with Russia has run its course.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Berlin in June 2012. Their countries have been trading partners, and rivals, for centuries.

item.title: Interactions of Bin Laden and Son-in-Law Detailed in an F.B.I. Document
item.description: Lawyers for Sulaiman Abu Ghaith, who is on trial on terrorism charges, sought permission from a judge to present the document, a full summary of his interrogation, to the jury.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:credit: Al-Jazeera, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Italian Leader Offers Plan to Fix Economy
item.description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi on Wednesday announced a $14 billion package of tax cuts and other measures intended to stimulate Italy’s stagnant economy.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Bishops Select Pope’s Confidant as New Leader
item.description: Cardinal Reinhard Marx, 60, the archbishop of Munich, was selected on Wednesday to lead the Roman Catholic bishops’ conference in Germany.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: More Protests and Deaths
item.description: A university student, a National Guard captain and a third man were shot to death in separate episodes Wednesday during antigovernment protests in Valencia.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Germany: Soccer Star’s Tax Dodge
item.description: Uli Hoeness, the beloved former Bayern Munich soccer player who is now manager of the German club, is under growing pressure to resign over a tax scandal.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Amid Search for Plane, Malaysian Leaders Face Rare Scrutiny
item.description: Worldwide bafflement at the disappearance of an airplane has challenged Malaysia’s paternalistic political culture and exposed its elite to withering judgments.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Malaysia’s defense minister, Hishammuddin Hussein, faced many questions at a news conference Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: Sudan: Police Fire Tear Gas After Funeral in Khartoum
item.description: Riot police officers on Wednesday clashed with protesters after the funeral of a student at the University of Khartoum.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Lincang Journal: Communism Is the Goal at a Commune, but Chinese Officials Are Not Impressed
item.description: A utopian farming commune in Yunnan Province probably would have pleased Chairman Mao, but the Communist Party has never had much tolerance for independent groups, and the community faces a campaign of intimidation.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Making noodles at the New Oasis for Life commune, which attracted people hoping to escape the smog, graft and social conservatism of contemporary Chinese life.

item.title: Russian Website Is Reined In Over Article on Ukrainian
item.description: A popular independent online news site, Lenta.ru, got a warning from the government about its Ukraine coverage, and then a new editor.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Obama Makes Diplomatic Push to Defuse Crisis in Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine’s interim prime minister, Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, visited President Obama and congressional leaders on Wednesday at a critical moment for his country.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Ukraine Prime Minister Arseniy Yatsenyuk entered the West Wing of the White House to meet with President Obama on Wednesday.

item.title: Afghan Militant Group Declares Itself Reporter’s Killer
item.description: A little-known Islamist militant group said it was behind the killing of Nils Horner in Kabul, claiming he was a spy for Britain.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Mattias Ahlm/Swedish Radio, via Associated Press

item.title: U.S. General Warns of Perils in Leaving Afghanistan
item.description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. told a Senate panel that the withdrawal of international forces would result in a resurgent Taliban and the creation of a safe haven for Al Qaeda.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: Gen. Joseph F. Dunford Jr. appeared Wednesday before the Senate Armed Services Committee.

item.title: Signals on Radar Puzzle Officials in Hunt for Malaysian Jet
item.description: Malaysian authorities were struggling to interpret data showing what could be the lost Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 veering off course and hundreds of miles from its last known position.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Indonesian Air Force officers at a base in Medan, Indonesia, examined a map of the Strait of Malacca after a search operation.

item.title: Opponent of Mexico’s Cartels Is Detained in Vigilantes’ Deaths
item.description: The founder of a self-defense group who became the public face of Mexico’s vigilante movement is suspected in the deaths of two members of a rival group.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:description: Hipólito Mora, who is from the southwestern state of Michoacán, has become well known in Mexico in connection with the vigilante movement.

item.title: European Union Takes Steps Toward Protecting Data
item.description: The prospects for the provisions to become law will depend on the 28 E.U. member governments giving their approval, which is highly uncertain.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Gaza-Israel Escalation Threatens Cease-Fire
item.description: The militant group Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility for a rocket attack, the most intense barrage since the cease-fire of 2012.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Theories Grow Without Facts on Lost Flight
item.description: On news programs and in chat rooms, aviation experts and the less informed tried to explain how a modern jet like Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 could disappear without a trace.
item.dc:creator: By ERIK ECKHOLM

item.title: In Beijing, Families of Missing Press for Action and Answers
item.description: The relatives and friends of the passengers of the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 are hungry for news of their loved ones, but little has come.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and BREE FENG

item.title: Pause Is Seen in a Continent’s Peopling
item.description: Linguists have found that a lost language was spoken in Beringia, a plain bridging Siberia and North America, and that its speakers migrated east and west.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS WADE

item.title: In His Second Year, Pope Faces Expectations That Change Is Coming
item.description: Widely praised and globally popular, Francis has raised expectations that he will bring major changes to the Roman Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis has been praised for his decisiveness in moving toward reform, but his public comments often seem ambiguous.
